I now can listen to people where before they'd talk and I'd go yep

column2: 13-18 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $3$1$3$I was about 12 years old or so when I started taking Adderall. People said they noticed an immediate difference- my grades improved
column3: I started paying attention
column4: I was more obedient. Then
column5: by the time I turned 13
column6: I began to have chronic stomach pains
column7: which continue to plague me to this day. At the time
column8: I was battling ADD
column9: depression
column10: anxiety... you name it. The stomach issues were just another thing to add to the list. By age 15
column11: I had an endoscopy
column12: and it discovered I had a condition known as Eosinaphililic Esophagitis (I think that's how it's spelled) as well as an ulcer. I continued taking medicine to treat everything
column13: until I had the idea to just stop taking my medicine altogether. That was at age 16. For more than a year and a half
column14: I experienced NO pain whatsoever from my stomach
column15: my depression faded
column16: and I was still able to focus as well as I was able to on the drug. I haven't taken it since
column17: as I haven't felt a need to
column18: though I still take the stomach medicine as needed. Bottom line- Adderall interfered with many of the other drugs I was taking to treat other things
column19: and kept me in a state of perpetual pain. But I was always alert and focused
column20: so technically
column21: the pill did its job. I don't see how everyone says this pill is addictive
column22: I find it far from that. During the time I was taking the medicine
column23: I continued to gain weight until I was nearly 300 pounds. Now
column24: it's been almost 2 years since I've taken them
column25: and the weight melted off naturally
column26: I'm down to 175- lighter than I've been in years. I feel better
column27: and I still can focus as well as I could on the drug
column28: despite not taking it. All in all
column29: I wouldn't really recommend taking this drug if you take other medicines in conjunction
column30: but it surely gets the job done if you don't mind the agony...

column1: 763$Condition: Attention Deficit Disorder with Hyperactivity$4/22/2011 11:44:05 PM$Reviewer: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $4$1$3$"Whether or not you have ""ADD"" adderall will help you concentrate
column2: get things done
column3: be more efficient etc.. Im a Senior in college.. 95% of people use it to study. If your kid says this isn't true.. they are lying.. or a freshman.. or from Idaho. I was tested and given 20mg pills... at first it was amazing. Not only could I sit down studying for my exams for 10 hours straight (literally) but it felt fun to study. Class was all of a sudden so interesting. Loooong story short
column4: after a few months of using it off an on (about 3 pills a week) the effects changed. Yes
column5: I could concentrate better when I was alone studying/doing school work. However
column6: when taking adderall I felt like some kind of zombie. Like.. I couldn't smile couldn't laugh
column7: didn't want to talk to anyone..(Im usually very extroverted). The day after taking adderall I sleep until about 2 or 3 pm. Ew! Typically I wake up at 7am and cannot sleep past 9 am! Once you start using the drug it is hard to get off it. Example: I am not physically dependent but when HUGE exams come along I mentally feel like I NEEED adderall. And yes
column8: I use it. (Stopping after graduation in a week). The mind is a powerful thing. Once you get off the drug
column9: once simple tasks may seem laborious. Final point:: I wish I never tried it. Also... I agree with a comment right below.. it is so sad that children are given this drug. Crazy. Try changing their diet.. brain teasers.. holistic options! Im a psychology major and we were just learning how on a basic-level naturalists perspective.. kids are not supposed to have great concentration because its a time to explore as much as they can as their highly plastic brains develop. Soak it all in! Helloooo people
column10: what elementary kid do you see sitting still & silent focusing on their workbook 24/7? Little adderrall robot antisocial children? Oh yea.. in all of my neuroscience courses we learned the chemical properties of the drug. Very similar to speed.. and cocaine. "

column1: 780$Condition: Attention Deficit Disorder with Hyperactivity$4/6/2011 6:53:22 PM$Reviewer: KB
column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $4$4$4$I take 10mg twice daily
column3: once in the morning ~8-9am
column4: and again between 12 and 1pm. Have been doing so for about 6-7 yrs. Only other ADD med I've tried was Ritalin for a short time
column5: which didn't seem as helpful.  Pros: Improved focus
column6: concentration
column7: motivation for boring/difficult tasks.  Cons: Insomnia
column8: which is why I could not tolerate the extended release
column9: and must make sure not to take the 2nd dose later than about 1pm. A small dose of Trazadone (25-50mg) has helped with the insomnia. Does take away appetite temporarily
column10: but I make sure to force myself to eat adequately
column11: b/c if not I am left feeling ravenous at the end of the day when it is wearing off
column12: and have a headache and feel more moody than usual.  Need to take a 'drug holiday' at least 1 day each week
column13: or else the med starts to feel less effective.  I do tend to 'hyperfocus' on things that I shouldn't necessarily be focusing on at that given time
column14: but I'm not sure if this is just a symptom of ADD itself or a symptom exacerbated by the medication. Do see this as being addictive in terms of feeling the need to stay on it (though why would I NOT feel like I should stay on it
column15: as it is helpful for my ADD).  However have not ever felt the need for a higher dose.  May increase levels of anxiety
column16: if this is an underlying problem you already have. Has been helpful for ADD symptoms
column17: but I've also realized it is not a magic cure
column18: and cannot stress enough the importance of being proactive in terms of learning your individual weaknesses and trying different ways to help overcome them.  WebMD has been helpful
column19: along with www.ADDitude.com and www.ThriveWithADD.com.  Would love to meet with a psychotherapist that specializes in ADD
column20: but haven't been able to find such a thing.  A life coach specializing in ADD would also be great
column21: but unfortunately is not covered by insurance and seems to be quite costly.  Overall has been helpful for me
column22: but do believe that everyone is affected differently.  Good luck!

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $4$3$5$I am 40 yrs. old and have been on Adderall 20 mg 2x a day for 2 yrs. now. I am also on a BP med and Effexor XR. After trial and error with other ADD meds found this to be most effective.  However at 3:30-4:00 pm in the afternoon it wears off.  I don't reallty know what to do with myself
column4: feel like I need a small dose to keep up with things I have to attend after work
column5: errands
column6: and in social settings. I am lucky to have a doctor who shares a real concern about the side effects in it increasing my heart rate.  She has already referred me to a cardiologist only to find that Adderall in combination with the other 2 meds raises my heart rate some.  Enough for her to put me on BP med taken everyday.  Sure there are some mild side effects of being tired but but there could be dangers in increasing the size of my heart down the road.  So the risks outweigh the mild side effects.  Just now need to bring to Dr's attention that I might need something for focus early evening.  Anybody out there who needs to take a small dosage of Adderall? Any suggestions?

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient) $5$1$4$"I took this drug from 2001 through 2010 and unfortunately never realized that this drug was the cause of intense calf pain and horrible circulation in my legs and hands. My feet used to literally turn blue. My legs in general were always bluish. I went to dozens of doctors over the past decade for a diagnosis. I even proactively asked the doctors if adderral could be causing the awful calf pain (which was the result of such poor circulation). The doctors all told me ""no"". FINALLY
column3: I found an incredible doctor who researched my pain extensively and told me that adderral may indeed be the cause of the freezing cold hands and feet
column4: as well as awful pain in my legs. Adderral is AWFUL to get off of. VERY DIFFICULT. I'm now off adderral and my pain is 90% better and I no longer have blue hands and feet. This drug can work wonders...but it has the potential to cause many health problems. "

column1: 803$Condition: Attention Deficit Disorder with Hyperactivity$3/7/2011 11:15:08 PM$Reviewer: Lionheart
column2: 19-24 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $5$4$4$"This medication has its pros and cons. I've never been able to focus on anything for more than 30 minutes at most
column3: especially with work and school. It took a while to figure out what worked for me
column4: but due to insomnia I use the instant release tablets since they wear off by the end of the day. I take 15 to 30 mg per day and it works wonderfully. I feel like I can actually function like ""normal"" people. The downside is that this is a stimulant so it will wake you up and makes sleeping difficult. It also causes a loss of appetite
column5: which can be rather difficult to deal with. After taking a dose
column6: it becomes nearly impossible to eat. Even forcing food down with liquids is a chore. It's as if food has no appeal or satisfying taste. Another negative side-effect of the instant release tablets is the comedown. Since this is a stimulant similar to speed/cocaine/meth
column7: it can have an intense comedown. I become very easily agitated (little things will set me off)
column8: I get headaches
column9: and I overall just feel sick. This is more intense if you haven't been eating throughout the day and if your taking a higher dose. Being aware of how crappy the comedown is makes it easier to deal with. I now can control my mood very well during my comedown and it now rarely affects me. I am not recommending this since it is an illegal solution (unless you have a medical prescription)
column10: but ""herbal"" use has been extremely helpful with the side-effects. Once my day is over and my comedown is beginning to make me feel sick
column11: a little greenery goes a long way. It removes all the negative moods and headaches
column12: restores my appetite
column13: and helps me fall asleep. I can not believe such a helpful drug is illegal
column14: because I would be (more) underweight and sick without it. It's what works for me and my prescribing psychiatrist is aware of my use
column15: but I'm not here to preach about it.

column1: Basically
column2: Adderall side-effects can be ROUGH
column3: but without it I could never manage to work 8 hour days or sit through night class."

column2: 19-24 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient) $4$3$5$"I have higher than normal blood pressure

column5: and repeat.

column1: Two weeks afterward

column3: I had an immediate urge to smoke.  It was to the point that I wanted to smoke up to a whole pack in a day.

column1: Being as it's a stimulant

column3: most of which killed off my libido and led to sexual dysfunction.  My libido went sky high
column4: but it destroyed my ability to perform.  I'm sure it was caused by the Adderall in addition to smoking because I checked my blood pressure about a month later and it spiked to 165/80.

column1: I also have seasonal depression
column2: and during this period the Adderall made me irritable.  Eventually
column3: the depression killed off the effects of Adderall.  I just started an antidepressant
column4: so hopefully this will correct it.

column1: Be very careful if you have high blood pressure
column2: smoke
column3: or consume excessive amounts of caffeine.  If you anxiety
column4: depression
column5: or bipolar disorder
column6: as I do
column7: you may have better results with the Adderall in treating ADHD."

817$Condition: Attention Deficit Disorder with Hyperactivity$2/16/2011 5:20:20 PM$Reviewer: Shyboi30
column2: 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $2$2$1$I'm a 30 year old white male who is a recovering addict from meth. I'm diagnosed with ADD w\o Hyperactivity. My life has been a stuggle. I lived with this disorder untreated for most of my life. this is how I found my way to meth addiction before I found out my real problem.  I want everyone to know that this medication is nothing like meth. A lot of people say that it is and a lot of people believe that it is. Let me
column3: being someone who has experienced both. Tell you that it is not at all the same.  To be honest with you I wish that it was. Do not think that in anyway I'm trying to say that meth is a good drug in anyway. What I'm saying is
column4: is that meth for people with ADD is a form of self medication and its addicting to us because we become normal people. I had high hopes that this medication would have some of the positive results that meth offers and none of the negative attributes of that drug.  I'm pretty sure I can tell you why this medication is addictive to people though. I've been on a lot of different medications and have learned well how to evaluate their effect on my life. This medication is the most difficult to figure out dosage and the most inconsistent medication I have ever dealt with. This medication can be addicting for us because we are tired of living our lives with ADD. When you take the medication and get varied and inconsistent results you want positive results so you take more to try to find that place where it helps you and remains effective. Its not a medication that you can just take the dosage when your supposed to and it will do what its supposed to. So far I'm not pleased with adderall. I will probably ask my doctor for something else on my next visit and pray that something else will work better for me. I know that this medication helps some people and I really wish that I was getting those kind of results. It would be nice to be able to speak with other people taking this medication and see what their experience has been like.

column2: 19-24 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $4$1$4$I have taken adderall for about 8 years now.  I have some mixed feelings about it.  I would not recomend it because of soo many mood swings
column3: and it is very addictive.  It really helps me like the hour after i take it and after that i feel tired and disinterested and not in a real good mood.  It also made me lose my appatite in the mourning and I would have to force me to eat then later on in the afternoon I would be starved cause i hadn't ate much earlier because the pills made me not hungry.  This stuff did calm me down to some extent but I became a whole different person when I was on this and it changed my personality and that was not a good thing.  My grades in school did greatly improve on this stuff.  And it does work immediatly when I take it.  I also noticed though when I took this it made me focus but made me focus on things I shouldn't be focused on.  This makes you feel awake when you first take it then like right after lunch time you feel completly ezhausted and you can't focus on anything
column4: plus i would get headaches every day.  This stuff did temperaily put you in a real good mood like 15 min after you take it then all the sudden you were in a bad mood.  This stuff works great for like a couple years
column5: then after a while you feel addicted to this drug and like it consumes your life.  There are too many ups and downs with this and a different moods every hour.  And without this drug I am not a moodie guy at all.  So I would not reccomend this stuff at all.  This stuff will mess you up.  Try Ritlen I took it for a while it seemed a bit better.

column1: 838$Condition: Other$1/21/2011 9:50:00 PM$Reviewer: $2$1$1$CAUTION: THIS MED CAN BE VERY DANGEROUS!!! Being in the medical industry and a user of adderall for nearly a year. Few significant things need to be said. While it did help me focus
column2: I also ended up in the emergency room with a 194/126 BLOOD PRESSURE. Muscle twitches were rampant. Horrific negative moods with sometimes uncontrolled verbal aggression are commonplace (within myself and patients I tend to). Sleeplessness goes without saying especially with XR (extended release). I also experienced confusion and dizziness (also reported by many patients). It causes excessive urination as well which tends to deplete your potassium (which helps maintain normal heart rhythms). Eat a banana. Dehydration is a bad side effect so drink plenty of water as well. You have to ask yourself...is focus and production increase worth the risk?

column1: 851$Condition: Attention Deficit Disorder with Hyperactivity$1/9/2011 9:36:15 AM$Reviewer: Help is out there!!
column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months$5$5$5$I have been on the generic adderall for about 4 months now 20mgs 2xday. It has worked wonders for me at work and my home life with the boyfriend. The hardest part is im a 2nd shifter. so i will stay up till like 4am and want to get up at 2 right before work. Making me feel like im rushing everywhere before i take my meds. I take my med at 2:30pm and at 7pm. B4 i got on it i had a hard time remember what my boss told me to do. I kept losing my tools for my job. i would forget to fill out all my paper work. And since i started taking it i'm very focused my rate has gone up. I remember where i leave stuff. I have always love to workout but
column3: now i stay more focused on my diet and exercise. And i have helpped many people around me with health issues and to get closer to God. It has helpped me so much. i wish now that my parents would of not been so against ADHD meds. when i was a kid i had a lot of trouble in school. I got alot of help from the teachers they would read my test to me so i could hear it and see it at the same time. I know now that i would of got better grades and not suffered so much if my parents would of not jugded everything by what they hear on the news about kids beating up kids for retalin on the bus. It has worked wonders and i dont plan on taking it my whole life it just has helpped me get my lifed turned around. I have always loved to make people smile with the dorky little things and sound effects i make just for fun and i know you make awesome sound effects to if you have the same prob:) I have not lost my wonderful personality. I am very greatful for the chance to get my life on track for once and not be lost in lifes smallest things anymore. I have tried concerta but was very expensive. and retalin but it made my stomach ache and i got mood swings. I hope i have helpped someone out there by them reading this. P.S i kick butt in video games now cause i can actually focus on them. God Bless you n i will pray for you. Pray for what meds u need:)

column1: 852$Condition: Other$1/8/2011 4:51:25 PM$Reviewer: pikachukiller84
column2: 25-34 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $3$3$5$"Hi
column3: I have never been diagnosed with anything or taken any medications until just recently. I am a 26 year old make and have been feeling very down for almost a year to the point of wishing to die everyday. I have always felt it even as a child
column4: but recently decided to seek help. The doctor prescribed me Celexa 20mg at first
column5: I took it for a couple weeks and really didnt notice anything. He upped it to 40mg/day (Celexa) and after about a month on it I started to notice a change. It happens pretty slow
column6: and it is subtle. But now I am much happier
column7: I can talk to my family now without getting an attitude
column8: and I have an overall feeling of ""life is good"". The only thing negative I noticed about it was sometimes I would feel zoned out
column9: or staring off into space. So the doctor prescribed me Adderall 10mg twice a day. I have only been taking the adderrall for about 4 days but let me tell you... this drug can work for you or against you. The first day I got it
column10: I didnt take it early enough and was up all night. The second day I took it in the morning
column11: and then in the afternoon. The first time taking it the feeling was intense. One pill makes you not feel much
column12: but after the second one you get euphoria that last's for about an hour or two and you have the feeling of being on coke or something. I was unclear for a couple of days how to use it because I didnt really feel like I could concentrate. So today I reduced it to one just before I took my test and found it to be ok. It isnt what I thought
column13: I know it would work better if I took the second dose
column14: but i didnt want to seem wired today
column15: and I wanted to get a goodnight sleep. As far as mood goes
column16: the Adderall put me in a really good mood
column17: non aggressive
column18: and also very relaxed (even though I felt wired and cracked out). I want to know what I should do
column19: because 1 dose in the morning is ok
column20: but the second one really enhances the situation
column21: clears my head up and allows me to concentrate
column22: but like I said the feeling for a few hour"

column1: 854$Condition: Attention Deficit Disorder with Hyperactivity$1/7/2011 12:44:51 PM$Reviewer: tiffanyannem1219
column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $5$5$5$"This treatment is the best thing that has ever happened to me....I was diagnosed with ADHD when I was a little kid. At the time my mother refused to put me on medication because she feared I would be put into special ed classes. I hated school
column3: with a passion. I was bored with what I was being taught
column4: and focusing on doing homework was impossible. After dropping out of high school
column5: and moving to a different state
column6: I got my GED and started college. I talked to my doctor about my problems in the past with ADHD and she started me out on Concerta
column7: which didn't do anything at all. She then switched me to Adderall XR 20mg once a day. For me this medicine is an absolute miracle. I can't believe the difference it has made in my ability to focus
column8: not only on school
column9: but living life in general.

column1: This drug definitely does not work for everyone. I have read a lot of reviews about children having negative reactions. A close friend of mine's son was taking 30mg a day at the age of 12. He also has MANY other psychological problems as well
column2: and Adderall turned him into a monster. His rage towards everyone around him was unbelievable. When he stopped taking it his behavior improved tremendously. In my opinion I think doctors are giving kids way too high of a dosage.

column1: Withdrawals from Adderall is a nightmare. I've taken a few breaks from it for about a month at a time within the past few years. I slept at least 16+ hours a day for a week straight. When I wasn't sleeping I was eating. The mood swings were terrible
column2: and I had NO patience for ANYTHING or ANYONE. But after about a week I was almost back to normal.

column1: Adderall sometimes makes me very compulsive.  I will occasionally obsessively pick at my skin
column2: and once I start its really hard to stop. Not many people experience that. Also as a smoker
column3: it makes me smoke A LOT.

column1: I also found that Vitamin C pretty much blocks Adderall from absorbing into the body. Once I stopped drinking juices w/ vit. C
column2: the Adderall worked normall"

column12: and you have depression and get panic attacks don't even think about touching Adderral or any other stimulant drugs. column5: with the PTSD I would not be able to go to sleep at night with racing thoughts about the war or I would go to sleep and wake up in sweating from horrible nightmares. Now it's like I have both going on except I seem to not have the racing thoughts about the war so much

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $4$4$4$"I've been on generic Adderal
column3: 10mg 3x day for three days. I had a sleep study and have a ""fragmented sleep pattern"" but just shy of having narcolepsy. After sleeping for 17 hrs a day for four years
column4: falling asleep while on the computer
column5: watching tv
column6: dozing off while shopping and doing dishes
column7: it's nice to wake up at 10am not 4pm. I was so depressed *because* I couldn't wake up
column8: not because of my depression which is well treated. My psychiatrist didn't care to listen. I'm still getting the timing right so I can sleep well at night. I do take meds for anxiety
column9: seizures
column10: atypical depression
column11: and tremors with muscular contortions. Thought adderal would really agitate all this but all I do is shake a little bit. I drag a lot between doses and my concentration goes away. I feel really physically hungry when I'm hungry
column12: but every food seems repulsive to me. I force myself to eat. I've had really tight muscles
column13: partly because of occasional contortions
column14: partly from adderal plus scoliosis. I do a lot of stretching and see my chiro. My pulse stays at 84 bps
column15: some very brief palpitations (one or two per day) so NO caffeine. I meditate and do breathing exercises. One very weird thing: Night sweats. Otherwise great. I'm awake all day
column16: can concentrate (no memory due to Topomax)
column17: and can do journaling and my art again plus be social. No more haze and I'm enjoying life for the first time in years! "

995$Condition: Attention Deficit Disorder with Hyperactivity$8/7/2010 4:16:09 PM$Reviewer: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $5$4$5$I was first prescribed Adderall XR when I was 16 years old. But in addition to that diagnoses of ADHD I was also told I had Bipolar Disorder. Now that I am in my 20s I have a worry about the long term side effects. Every doctor I have asked assures me that there are no proven negative long term effects of taking this medication for a long period of time.  But I can help but think otherwise. It is an amphetamine after all. Other issues I am concerned about have been the effect it has on me when I stop taking it completely. I am very tired and don't really know what to expect or I'm aware of things that are going on around me but can't really grasp the concepts. I have tried the none Extended Release Adderall and it was very unsatisfactory! BLEH! I would take one in the morning and then one in the afternoon and I had major side effects
column2: tremors
column3: ticks
column4: I kept clenching my jaw and I was very unhappy. I am satisfied with the results and ease of the XR tablets. But I still think about the long term side effects...kind of feel like a lab rat considering every doctor I've asked about them seems to think that I'll be fine...I guess I'll find out
column5: eventually...

column1: 1005$Condition: Other$7/27/2010 10:49:50 AM$Reviewer: Linda
column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $5$5$5$"**** Adderall helped me get through an intensive graduate school program by allowing me to focus on my reading assignments and projects after a long full day at work. It also elevated my mood. I felt happy that I was managing work and school well. I never abused the dosage and took it on a daily basis with the approval of my doctor for a year and a half until I suffered from a ruptured brain aneurysm. I never had high blood pressure and my EKG was fine before starting the medication. I did notice that my BP had gone up while on the medication but I just attributed that to the extra demands of grad school and a new teaching position. I was one of the Extremely lucky ones to survive the ruptured aneurysm w/o complications. My neurosurgeon said that the rupture could have been brought on by the use of this drug and demanded I immediately stop using it. Because of this I would not recommend it's use by anyone. I'm a teacher and would rather see kids or adults bouncing off the walls or daydreaming away then lying in a coffin.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient) $4$2$4$For the lady with is worried about her 29 year old daughters hair falling out.  I am 26 years old and have taken adderall since i was 13.  So pretty much everything that most of the things people are saying they are going through in these reviews
column3: they have already come and gone with me.  But the last is the hair loss with me.  Right now Im going to a dermatologist just to figure out my massive hair loss problem.  I fear I will almost be bald by the end of the year (but mostly because my last dermy was a moron and never even ran tests). My suggestion is get her to a Dr.  Get a blood test or test the scalp tissues.  Thyriod/depression/stress/hormones are easily grouped and can be disguised.  And with this disorder is hard to figure if its just you or could actually be an underlining problem.  I have my other dermys apt tomorrow.  Ill respond when i have a better problem with whats going on with me because i can almost guarantee it might be the same thing.

column1: 1060$Condition: Attention Deficit Disorder with Hyperactivity$6/5/2010 12:48:55 AM$Reviewer: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $5$4$5$I have struggled with ADHD symptoms since I can remember.  I only recently started taking medications as my symptoms got worse after having children.  I tried Ritalin before switching to Adderall.  It has helped me more than anything I have ever tried to do on my own (making schedules
column2: writing notes & reminders
column3: not taking on too many things at once).  It just made life so much easier.  I don't have accidents at work
column4: I focus better
column5: I finish what I start and dont procrastinate.  I also am able to get to work on time and not be as stressed and irritable.  However
column6: I have been on it for two years and I have had issues with not being able to take it for a few days or a week sometimes and I definitly felt that there was a dependence even after taking the correct dosage always.  I dont like the fact that Adderall is so addictive whether you abuse it or not.  I want to be put on something else so I dont have to worry about that
column7: but i think that the outcome outweighs the risk...unless another medication can do the same job without being as addictive physically.

column1: 1061$Condition: Other$6/4/2010 9:13:34 PM$Reviewer: Bill Mc
column2: 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $5$5$5$"Male
column3: Age 60
column4: for Adult ADD. Taking it approx 18 months. Prescribed generic Adderall 20mg twice daily. Usually split the dose into 10mg 2 or 3 times a day. Skipping dose completely 2 days in a row each week so as to not have to increase the dosage. Works very well for me.  Helps me to focus and accomplish what ever I may be working on. Also more sociable and more tolerant of others. Good for anger management. Spouse notices the difference and supportive of my taking it. Some initial weight loss 5 - 8 lbs but have since regained it.  Just eat at meal times and try more highly seasoned food (easy on the salt).  Also drink more liquids. Best to not take it late in the day unless you plan on being up late. I still sleep at night and usually take a nap in the afternoon. Some people complain about excessive side effects and not liking the results.  Well see your MD and maybe try something else.  As for me
column5: ""it's just what the Doctor ordered"".  Wish I had known about this medication years ago.  It's a real help for me. My results far outweigh any side effects
column6: which I find to be minimal."

column1: 1112$Condition: Other$4/14/2010 6:30:17 AM$Reviewer: paintedacres
column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $5$4$5$I found out that I was ADD almost two years ago. I never figured in a million years that I was until she described my issues to a (T). I agreed to start taking this drug and in the beginning it was a shocker. I was so amazed how alert and focused I was and wished I would have had this throughout school. I did well in school due to getting beat if I didn't but I could have done a lot better and at least been able to retain the information. As an adult I have found it very hard to keep my impusliveness under control. I have issues with spending. I am not a shopaholic but I buy for other people when I know I shouldn't and I over eat very badly even when I am stuffed. I can't control it. It eats at me until I almost have a panic attack. When I buy things it is always for other people not myself. This drug has helped somewhat with that. It at least makes me think about it first. But while I am doing better with it
column3: it still is not cured. I still struggle with the eating and the buying everyday. At first it helped with the eating quite a bit. Now after a year or so the effect has worn off and I tend to eat more than I did however not as much as it was before. My doctor says that you dont get used to the drug and need to take more. You only do if you misuse it. Well I have not misused and I can tell you it doesn't work like it did and I find myself needing to take 3 to 4 10mg pills (fast acting) when before and even now my script says to take 2. I am scared to go off the med since it is helping in my job and keeping me on track but I am scared to keep on with it and get to where I am abusing. I don't think I ever will however I am getting used to it. I am also scared to take other meds for add since a few times I have changed scripts for depression and it has messed me up.

While her school performace has improved greatly as well as her ability to complete her homework, when the med wears off in the evening, she becomes irritable, moody and beligerant with us.  We will be considering a different medicine for her.
1153$Condition: Attention Deficit Disorder with Hyperactivity$2/17/2010 1:54:14 PM$Reviewer: 7-12 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Caregiver) $5$5$5$My son is in 4th grade & had extreme difficulties at school such as focus,comprehension,accumulating info, disorganized,not being able to finish the work in class, math, etc. He was also diagnosed a couple of years ago with DAMP. He was on Ritalin for a couple of months 2 yrs ago & stopped since we did not see any improvement. we were at the point of desperation & had enough frustrations & so did he!Therefore eventhough I was very much against drugs we decided that he needs help so let's give it another try! His dr. prescribed Adderall 10mg/day in the AM before breakfast- a miracle has been brought upon my son & our family!! it works wonderful, amazing! the only side affects that I noticed are the loss of appetite (which I am not too upset over since he is about 6 lbs. overweight & noticed that he is hungry in AM, so I give him a healthy breakfast) and sensitivity (he easily cries if someone gets him upset).Other than that there have been no other side affects. we are all extremely happy to see him do extremely well at school. He was never hyper, but had some behavior problems - even that has changed for the better.  He interacts & socialized better w/friends. Prior to this med his grades were Cs and Ds; ever since he started on Adderall the test results are amazing; A's in social studies and B+ in math!!  Not only that it makes everyone happy (his family as well as teachers)that he's doing so well but he is very well aware of it & I can see the happiness that he did not have before when he comes home with good grades & ease at learning!! He has built confidence & holds his head up high!! Thank you Dr. Weidner!!!...& of course Adderall!  I shall return & review this med in a couple of month & let everyone know if he's still doing just as well and/or if the side affects have changed!
1154$Condition: Attention Deficit Disorder with Hyperactivity$2/13/2010 11:11:15 PM$Reviewer: a3gill, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $5$5$5$Adderall has been a lifesaver. I took Ritalin as a kid and developed some nervous ticks. So
column2: I dropped it
column3: and tried to manage without. I did fine until college reading emerged.

column1: I have a ridiculously high dosage
column2: but it works great for me
column3: other than nasty looks that I get from Pharmacists thinking that I am a dealer.(that buys inventory with insurance...LOL) My dosage is steady now
column4: but for about the first year
column5: it was increased each month. That’s probably just me though
column6: my body doesn’t respond well to medicine.

column1: Reading comprehension has always been my biggest hurdle
column2: non-technical reading is virtually impossible for me. Just below reading is hanging-in with poor lecturers. I need to have genuine interest in something or my mind will promptly begin to wander. If a teacher shows the end goal and it appears interesting
column3: then the uninteresting stepping stones become interesting
column4: because they are required to get to the concept that you want to know. Conversely
column5: if a teacher presents each building block as something to know
column6: ""because I said so
column7: then I will be staring out the window before they finish their sentence.

column1: Since arriving at the correct dosage
column2: I can now do anything that I want. Not only are my problem areas fixed
column3: but other aspects have improved as well. The best way that I can describe it is having a librarian roaming around in your brain. My capacity for learning has gone off the charts
column4: my memory retention and recollection is ridiculous
column5: and the boost of energy really shines though in self-motivation. And
column6: above all
column7: I now spend at least 2-4 hours per day reading anything that I want.

column1: To put my improvement in context
column2: I took my ACT’s un-medicated. My best score was a 29/36.

column1: Hmm
column2: it’s okay
column3: but look at the pieces:

column1: Math: 36/36
Science Reasoning: 35/36
English: 32/36
Reading: 14/36
I noticed the benefits most
column2: when I lost them with my insurance for a month. Not withdraw symptoms
column3: having to deal with my old flawed brain. I was spoiled.

column1: 1247$Condition: Attention Deficit Disorder with Hyperactivity$10/1/2009 9:31:07 AM$Reviewer: 35-44 Female  (Patient) $4$2$3$I am 38 yr old mother of two. My experience is the time release(XR) is the best form the non time release feels like you are on a roller coaster.  The time release is very smooth.  Although I started on 20mg I believe after 5 years on this and now down to 5mg a day this is a very hard drug on my body as a women.  I have two best friends on it and although we love the weight it keeps off and how organized we think we are on it we all believe there is a dark side to this drug that no one talks about. Everyone seems OK in our lives except our husbands.  There is an edgy/anger piece that goes along with this drug..  I think it effects our hormones in some way.  My suggestion is start on a lower dose and move up but I am looking for more natural choices because I think this drug makes life go by very quickly.  I also think as a women you can not help but get addicted to the way you burn more calories and it automaticly suppresses your appetite.  If you are on this and are having relationship problems then you might want to look at this drug as a reason and not other outside things. Also I think if you take the wrong dose it can actually make it harder to complete some things. This drug is in the same family as Meth amphedemines.  If you take this drug you should really think about the similarities to being a junkie!! I stopped taking it for 6 months and gained 30 pounds and I started sleeping a lot and my house became a disaster.  There is probably something better out there
column2: but I have not found it.

column1: I did not get it officially diagnosed until I was 50 years old.  I knew the stigma of Narcolepsy would interfere with job searching. 1256$Condition: Attention Deficit Disorder with Hyperactivity$9/18/2009 12:05:06 PM$Reviewer: GEElo, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient) $4$4$3$Taking Adderall XR with suboxone makes a pill cocktail. The high from those two drugs combined is a whole new ball game. First of all Docs know nothing but to see you on your appointment and then get rid of you. If they payed any attention they would know that a person with a history of drug or alcohol abuse should not take adderall or adderall xr. But then again they keep us coming back for business. So, would that make them a legal drug dealer. Yes, it would. I had a chemical dependency to perscription painkillers. I realized something was really bad when I was taking them just to be able to function from day to day. I sought help because things were all jacked up. If I could make a difference in someone's life just by writing this little piece then all the pain I caused myself and everyone around me, then I would have to say it was worth it. If you have a chemical dependency the first thing you do is decide weather or not you want to continue that way of life, which is extremely painful. Second, commit to yourself in getting well. You will need a really good support system to help you through it. With hard work and dedication to yourself you will succeed. If you follow those three rules you will get through it with out a dought. If I had to go through it again I would have gone to the psychiatrist to get on suboxone so I could wing myself through it. I was on suboxone for one year exactly. If I would have just listened to my brother and not got on the suboxone I would have gotten over the emotional withdrawl after about 5 to 7 days. The physical withdrawls(tiredness,unmotivated)would eventually pass around three to four weeks. So, you could get through it in a months time verses getting on suboxone and wasting a year of your life.

column1: 1262$Condition: Attention Deficit Disorder with Hyperactivity$9/10/2009 12:44:27 PM$Reviewer: lil'learner
column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $4$4$4$I've struggled with ADD my entire life but my parents were totally against medicating me (thank you mom and dad) Instead they made an effort to get me help from tutors and personal coaches that taught me good organizational and study habits which helped a bit. I struggled all through out my 6 years of college and now at 26
column3: moving into the ranks of working for myself and taking on several projects
column4: I could really use some help. My buddy gave me some adderall and I probably got more work done in 2 weeks than my 6 years of college- mainly because I neither ate nor slept for days at time. I also found that I was able to pop these like skittles with frightening ease. I couldn't see taking this medication daily as I wouldn't risk my physical and psychological well-being for any amount of work or money. I believe this should be used as a last resort. One thing I have learned is to observe my work habits while on adderall vs. when I'm not and try to mimic those behaviors daily. This drug is certainly a tool for success but I feel that it shouldn't be used as a way of living.

column1: 1264$Condition: Attention Deficit Disorder with Hyperactivity$9/9/2009 3:20:42 PM$Reviewer: absent_minded
column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $4$4$5$"I was started out on 20mg of Adderall Oral daily (in the morning). But currently
column3: my dosage has been increased to 30 mg each morning
column4: with the option to take another 10 to 20 mg later on in the day during long work days. I have an ADHD sufferer's worst nightmare for a job: I'm mostly a paper-pusher/interviewer. I'm a social worker for a corrections department. I have piles of paperwork everyday. I also teach decision-making and social skills classes
column5: which also require a lot of planning and organization. I had been able to negotiate with and compensate for my ADHD all through grade schools
column6: high school
column7: and college. However
column8: my condition became dibillitating at my first ""career"" job with the massive amounts of paperwork and organization I was expected to perform. I'm in my early 20s and began treatment for ADHD at the beginning of August. I feel that the medication has helped me immensely. My family
column9: fiance
column10: and coworkers have all noticed the change in my work habits and all-around behavior. I'm quieter
column11: more focused
column12: and less apt to ""fly off the handle"" for minor things that don't seem to make much sense to anyone else. I'm pretty satisfied overall with my results. That said
column13: I do experience some side effects. I have had pretty significant loss of appetite as well as weight loss. But for me
column14: its not a major issue at the moment as I was already considered somewhat overweight by my doctor when I started the medication. If I continue to lose at this rate
column15: I suppose it could become a problem. I also experience dry mouth pretty badly. I sometimes get it so bad that my whole mouth feels ""fuzzy."" But luckily
column16: I'm allowed to keep a drink on my desk at work :) Also
column17: I occasionally experience headaches that I believe are related to the medication. But these aren't very often. All in all
column18: there's some drawbacks/side effects
column19: but the benefits far outweight them."

column2: 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $5$4$5$"I was diagnosed with ADD at age 41
column3: and prescribed 20mg 1x/day. It helped a little but not enough to cause me to really follow a treatment track with enthusiasm...typical ADD. Anyway
column4: I am now 46; I have had 4 different employers in that time
column5: plenty of stress
column6: depression
column7: anxiety
column8: low self esteem
column9: etc. Three years ago
column10: I had the double sleep study which revealed that I have narcolepsy. So now
column11: my sleep specialist has me taking 30mg XR in the morning
column12: and Adderall tabs of 20mg at 9am/noon/3pm for a total of 90mg/day. I have gone through highs and lows with this drug - more highs than lows. I think that the biggest drag in this whole process is that Adderall is just a daytime life support system for my exhaustion; it does enable me to focus
column13: hustle
column14: retain instructions
column15: etc. But - I still have an incurable sleep disorder which never allows me to get restorative sleep. I am definitely addicted to Adderall; I get anxious when my doctor goes on vacation because he has done it in the past
column16: without notice! Needless to say
column17: I am changing doctors. Finally
column18: I can relate to people that complain about the zombie effect. I have a great ability to entertain my family and friends with my humor
column19: and sometimes it will just disappear for days. My new doctor said that he is worried about my heart; I told him that I am at peace with ""death by heart attack"". He was not amused. I wasn't trying to be funny
column20: just pragmatic. I need my Adderall and I think it works great for the right patient. "

column1: 1277$Condition: Attention Deficit Disorder with Hyperactivity$8/11/2009 5:54:45 PM$Reviewer: rmhill10
column2: 7-12 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $5$4$5$Adderall has helped me focus so much better and I have went to C's and D's to A's and B's in my grades.  My teachers have actually came up to me and asked if I  was the same person who was in their clas a week ago.  It has helped me get through fourth through sixth grade.  The only problem I have is that it made me want to do evreything at once and that really stressed me out.  I got mild depression becuase of that and I'm now taking an antidepressant AND Adderall.  It's kind of hard to remember to take both the drugs and I somtimes miss a few day on one or both of the drugs.  This drug worked on me but please find out exactly what it does to you before making a comitment to taking it.  Ask your doctor if you can start on the lowest dosage possible and graduly work your way up untill you find a dosage right for you.  Like any other medication it is a hit or miss and you should stop taking it if it worsens your condition or if you have side effects lasting longer than two weeks.  I hope my information helped!

column1: 1281$Condition: Attention Deficit Disorder with Hyperactivity$8/4/2009 1:09:43 PM$Reviewer: TheDoc
column2: 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Caregiver) $5$5$5$"As a Doctor myself
column3: I have to stress that when it comes to Adderall in either the XR or IR forms
column4: there is no grey area. There are those patients who do extremely well on this medication and others who were perhaps misdiagnosed or physiologically intolerant of the chemical makeup of the drug. The bottom line is: If you need it
column5: it can work wonders. However
column6: if you're one of those who doesn't truly suffer from ADD ADHD-Hyp
column7: then you may gain some benefits
column8: but you will also have more incidence of negative side-effects. My personal experience with the IR has been wonderful. Most everyone has the associated loss of appetite
column9: and general ""fidgety"" feeling when starting treatment
column10: but these do subside. However
column11: they have a nasty habit of resurfacing later on in treatment. This usually accompanies an increase in dosage
column12: but can pop up for seemingly no reason at all. The best advice I can give regarding treatment with amphet salts is: If you need it
column13: then it can help tremendously. However
column14: if you don't need it
column15: you're better off with those awful energy drinks or a few cups of coffee. Hope this helps."

column3: goodnatured young man became cruel

column5: risky sexual behavior
column6: and would lie about anything.  It was like a alien had taken over my son's body.  It has been a nightmare and I would never encourage any parent to give this drug to their children.  My son has been off of it for about 1 week and right now he is a fragile shell who has suffered with depression
column7: vomiting

column9: enthusiatic young man back.

1297$Condition: Attention Deficit Disorder with Hyperactivity$7/17/2009 7:37:52 PM$Reviewer: 19-24 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $4$4$4$I am a college student and have been started taking Adderall because I have been on a downward slope academically since my freshman year of high school to now. Although I have had problems with paying attention, getting started with projects, etc., I was able to get by. The work in school, naturally, has become harder. I have been a B/C student for awhile now. For the last month, I have yet receive any assignment that is less than an A. Menatlly, this drug has helped. Physically, not so much. I have noticed that I am more hyperactive. I am constantly fidgeting with my hands and my legs are shake profusely. Also, my eating habits are terrible. I was at a slim 135 pounds to begin with before I began the medication and I know for a fact that I will have lost weight the next time I see my doctor. One side effect is loss of appetite. This effect is extremly noticeable. For me, I very very rarely feel hungry. Just last week I forgot to eat ANYTHING for two straight days. Overall though, if you are careful and responsible this is an effective and easy-to-use drug. Hopefully, this helps.

1313$Condition: Attention Deficit Disorder with Hyperactivity$6/23/2009 5:16:35 PM$Reviewer: Jess, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient) $4$4$5$I've been diagnosed with ADHD since age 6, I am now 26 years old.  I'm overall satisfied with this medication.  I noticed that my mood seems to be more even, I have a better handle on my disorder versus the other medications I've taken, and most of my other symptoms are under control.  I have noticed weight loss but my doctor told me before hand that it would happen. Being that I gained some weight after I stopped my previous medication, I didn't mind that too much.  I have also noticed more dry-mouth than my other medications so I'm drinking a lot more water through the day, but I don't mind that so much as I drink a good amount of water anyway.  One thing that I will have to say is that I keep having to 'readjust.'  My doctor, who I love, started me on an extreme low dose and is working me up to my 'stable' point which has spanned over 8 months now.  Getting to the point of 'stable' is my biggest issue since precautions have to be taken. Due to the nature of this drug, that the risk of addiction is high, my doctor and I are taking it slow.

I started taking adderall at the age of twelve. When i was on the drug it was very effective. It helped me concentrate in school, calmed me down from acting out, and helped prevent me from doing bad things. Although it has done good, it has also done bad. For example, i started losing weight because i never had an appetite, i became more distant with people because i was quiet all the time from focusing on things, and i also became needy of it all the time. I have been off of the pills for about a year now and I'm doing just fine. It is extremely hard to get out of the habit of needing them. It takes time to get out of the habit, but eventually it will work. Trust me.  Adderall can be very addictive and although it can benefit you, it may also destroy you in some ways. So one tip to take into consideration if you want to start taking adderall is to start off at a low dosage and work your way up until you feel it is doing its job.

1326$Condition: Attention Deficit Disorder with Hyperactivity$6/8/2009 10:35:36 PM$Reviewer: $3$3$1$I am junior in high school and have been taking adderall for 3 years. At first it seemed like a miracle drug. My grades went up considerably and I felt that I had gained a sense of control. I was prescribed 30mg a day including one 20mg pill of adderall xr. The side effects were harsh in the beginning and I lost a lot of weight. The next 2 years I would take it regularly still having the same side effects but very mild. In short
column2: I could go off the pill and feel fine for any amount of time. But I began to feel a sort of dependence on the drug about a year after. The loss of appetite seemed to be a motivation for me to be thin so i started to up my dose a little bit. My grades went from a 3.3 to a 2.7 and so i figured I was immune to the drug so I started to take even more. For the past about 6 months I have regularly been taking at the least 50mg and at most 70mg a day. Sometimes I don't know why I am taking it I just do. I can honestly say in the past week I have slept in total maybe 10-15 hours some nights not sleeping at all. My heart is constantly pounding and my hands are always shaking. I hate it but i can't help it. My parents dont hide my pills or anything and dont keep track of when they get it so it makes it easy for me.I am always very moody and today I had a nutri grain bar and thats it but I dont even feel hungry. I didnt think drugs prescribed to myself could be so addictive but they are. I suggest people not to take them to begin with.

column2: 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient) $5$5$5$"I have been taking Adderall since last November (08).  I was started on 20mg of Adderall xr
column3: then went to 25 mg xr

column6: 10mg
column7: around noon to one p.m.  I think Adderall works great
column8: the problem I had was that even though it is an XR formulation it seemed to wear off around noonish everyday.  I was never able to get ""all day coverage"". This is what worked for me.  I was worried about sleep issues being on this dose
column9: the amazing thing is I actually feel like I sleep better since being on this medication. column10: it's makes it more difficult for people who use it for legitimate medical purposes to get it.  All of my other medications I can get a 90 day supply in the mail. column2: 45-54 Female  (Patient) $5$5$5$"I am a 49 yr female... I always knew I was differrent. I felt like information went into my brain but went right out the other side. I would read
column3: listen to a lecture or be in a conversation and end with no recollection of the information I was given. How was I to explain this to a doctor... I thought they would think I was crazy. I rehearsed over and over what I would say to them to make them believe there truely was a problem. How much easier it would be to go in and show them a cut
column4: bruise or broken bone... they could fix it. How could they diagnose or fix a problem they couldn't see and I couldn't explain. I spent 7 years in and out of the doctors office. She first put me on prozac
column5: treated me for an inter-ear infection
column6: had me get all of my old fillings replaced
column7: got glasses
column8: treated me for allergies
column9: etc. All these things were good but there was still something much more. She gave up
column10: one day she said ""I can't help you"". Talk about a heart break and a validation that I was crazy. One day I read an ad on Straterra... explaining the symptoms of adult ADHD. I asked my doctor if there were special test for that. She said yes
column11: as she rolled her eyes
column12: but she would have to refer me to a shrink...here we ago again!

column1: The psycologist had me diagnosed in moments. No special tests were needed. The Straterra has helped for about 6 years now but there was still something more that I couldn't put my finger on. I have been going to doctors now for another 3 years to finally get one to take my extreme fatigue seriously. I took a sleep test and I have mild narcolepsy. My doctor has recently added adderall and I am finally content that what I have been silently struggling with all my life has been discovered and properly treated. I breaks my heart to pieces to think I raised my 3 children without this help. I struggled so badly just to make it through each day and hide my feelings of ""stupidness"". Now at almost 50
column2: I feel like I have a clear mind...and a new start on life.   "

I think my b/p was a little high before I started adderall so not sure if its directly the adderall.I do have loss of appetite again but have not lost any weight. Which sucks!! But I have only been on adderall for about a month. So maybe I just didnt lose it yet.When I first started taking the meds last summer I did sometimes take up to 40 mg in one day.I know Im not supposed to but I would if I wanted to study or get up early the next day. My fatigue/sleepiness gets so bad sometimes I physically cant get up in the morning. And sometimes I can sleep like a whole day. So maybe thats why I lost more weight
column5: too. Has anyone else had these side effects that I am now having? I have an app. with my primary physician this week for the high b/p. Just to make sure all is ok. Im only 30 yrs old and dont want heart probs.now!! But I like the adderall and hope I can stay on it."

I have now noticed that I bruise easily, my limbs become numb and tingly occasionally and my circulation seems to be altered a little to where I have noticed it cant be good. My feet do swell and they turn purple if I apply a little pressure to them. My perception of objects seem to be a little off cause i run into everything. I also keep these lumps under my scalp? It seems to stay in the same top portion of my scalp and it just feels lumpy like theres fluid or something trapped in there. Would like to find out if anyone is experiencing the same things. 1357$Condition: Attention Deficit Disorder with Hyperactivity$4/15/2009 6:05:46 PM$Reviewer: stepford41, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $1$1$3$I have been chronically late most of my life so much so it has cost me jobs. Etc. I also was the kid who just looked out the window in grade school. My psych, decided to give me a test and bam, I have ADD. and was given the generic version. After reading these reviews, I can relate. I have horrible tirade mood swings, I don't feel like I am getting more work done during the day, I focus on things that are not a priority,like ebay. I also leave the office so exhausted I feel like I have lost me. I have no energy to do anything. Errands are a big deal, working out, forget it. I feel like I have no time, because I waste a lot of it. Procrastinating. It is ruining my life. The only good thing is it keeps my hunger at bay, and my weight is at 120. I think I am taking more and more to keep awake during the day. What is so wonderful, your doc gives you this stuff, and no one tells you to watch for side effects. I wonder if I was off all these meds how I would be. I am 41 and feel like a 90 year old taking a bunch of pills each day. One to bring me up, one to bring me down, one for depression one for anxiety. I have never been one to lose patience, and I lose it all the time. I have ruined relationships because of it. I react, don't think.  I feel like I need rehab.

column2: 35-44 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $5$5$5$"I come from an good middle class
column3: educated family and discovered that I was ADD recently.

Well I have always been very ant-meds but I was still very curious to try and see what meds could perhaps do for me.  My ADD symptoms have been fatigue
column3: innattention
column4: foggy thinking
column5: procrastination to name a few.  For the last week I have been taking 10 mgf of Adderall twice daily.  Although I have only taken the medication for 5 days it has been really helping me tremendously.  I am calm and relaxed and I can comfortably sit still.  I have a lot more patience for my son and I feel better in general.  I think people should however be very careful with this medication and take it very carefully. For me this medication has (for the very short time I have tried it) been a huge help. "

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient) $5$4$5$This is a Reply to the woman who posted a question on 3/20/09.... Edema (Swelling/Fluid) in the ankles & feet is a seriouse side effect from Adderal and indicates a circulatory problem (blood flow) usually due to a heart problem. Most likely a temporary side effect but a serious one. If you stop taking the drug
column3: symptoms should go away unless serious damage has been done or it's poss it could be related to another condition or a drug/food interaction with Adderall. Call your doctor/pharmacist. Also
column4: Review drug info on WebMD.

column1: 1383$Condition: Attention Deficit Disorder with Hyperactivity$3/2/2009 11:11:26 PM$Reviewer: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $4$4$5$"I have been on Adderall for almost 2 years now. I like the XR pills MUCH better than the fast acting pills
column2: but can no longer afford them due to recently losing my job and health insurance. I used to take 25mg (XR) in the morning and that worked well
column3: and I noticed less side effects.  Now I take 10mg of the generic amphetamine salts 2 x's a day. Since starting on the medication I have less difficulty prioritizing my day and schedule
column4: retaining information
column5: starting and finishing tasks
column6: and paying attention in general. On the other hand
column7: I have developed nervous habits I can't break like biting my lips
column8: playing with my nails and a crazy desire to smoke
column9: feel awkward in certain social situations (which is TOTALLY not me)
column10: feel edgy and moody at the end of most days
column11: and sometimes have trouble making fast decisions and conveying my thoughts clearly. Over all
column12: I feel the benefits of the drug outweigh the negative side effects (I used to be a total spaz and be asked almost daily if I was ""on crack""
column13: which really messed with my self esteem) so I continue to take it
column14: but I can’t help but wonder if I should try something else.  Any suggestions?"

Basically

column2: 35-44 on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years$5$5$4$I am a successful nationally known professional advertising photographer who was on Adderall for about five years and then decided that I did not need it anymore because all of my old ADHD habits where mostly gone. I was off of them for about three months and all of those long gone adhd habits that had played havoc with my life started coming back one by one. Unpaid parking tickets
column3: loosing my keys
column4: rash decisions
column5: unfinished project after unfinished project. Within six months I had almost lost my photography business that I had worked so hard for and had collections agencies after me etc.  Wow what a bust to my ego! I guess I really do need to be on Adderall. It's as if when I am not on Adderall I know exactly what it is I need to do to keep my life running smooth...I put together my to do list but the to do list never gets completed. Yes I am a successful advertising photographer with lots of talent...but without the discipline and focus to apply that talent my world falls apart. I guess I just need to take it...it is what it is. I know there are lots of talented artists who take adderall...and I do not feel it makes me any less creative....or for that matter any more creative. How one little adderall XR pill makes the difference between being reasonably disciplined and totally irresponsible
column6: however
column7: is beyond me...but for me the reality is just that. I am now back on Adderall 20 MG XR and things are going great again. Hope this was helpful to any other artists out there who are struggling with the to medicate/not to medicate question. In my case the choice was made for me...I do not even think I would still be in business without this drug..no kidding.

column1: 1441$Condition: Attention Deficit Disorder with Hyperactivity$11/27/2008 10:18:49 AM$Reviewer: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $4$4$5$I have had ADHD
column2: most likely since I was a young kid (I'm now 24)
column3: but diagnosed a little over 1 year ago.  I recently finished graduate school
column4: and stopped the Adderall since I stopped seeing the MD.  Now that I've been back on it (about 2 weeks) I'm much more focused
column5: I don't drift off when I'm speaking to clients and feel more motivated to finish my work on time.  I'm also  not binging as often as I used to
column6: which is extremely helpful since I have gained 10 pounds in the last 6 months.  I don't feel aggressive or angry to the point where its affecting my life and hurting others.  Of course
column7: I still have to make some behavioral changes to improve my organizational skills
column8: but that's not something any medication can fix.  Don't expect it to change everything
column9: as part of the treatment for ADHD is to learn new tools to combat the symptoms.  This medication is not a good idea if you or any family members have a history of substance abuse or dependence
column10: since you are predisposed to those conditions.  If you have any psychiatric issues in addition to the ADHD
column11: you must speak with your doctor about them
column12: since treatment will be counterproductive.  You play the greatest role in your treatment-not the medication.

column2: 13-18 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $5$4$4$"I began taking adderall at 15mg when I was in the 4th grade (2001-2002) I lost about 28 pounds almost immediatly which was not a bad thing because I was about 30 pounds over weight. My doctor moved me down to 12 mg to stop the weight lose
column3: which it did. I did however notice that it was not working as well so I was placed back onto 15 mg. The 15 mg dosage no longer worked as well as it originally did so I was bumped up to 20 mg and than once again to 25mg and in the 8th grade I was finally bumped up to 30mg where I remain to this day in the 11th grade.

column1: Side effects I have experienced:
Lose of Weight
Lose of Apetite
Depression
O.C.D symptoms (extermely prevelent in my last two years)
Anxiety
Paranoia
P.T.S.D

It is strange I go through a living hell almost day by day which may or may not be because of the Adderall but I can not just stop taking it because I fear being the way I am when I'm off of it during my everyday life because I get really ""crazy"" when I am not on it and eat a lot and just am moody and its pretty bad so I stay on it even though sometimes (more than less) I feel like a am losing my mind. I sometimes wonder what I would be like today if 8 years ago I had not been put on Adderall. (I actually did not have ADHD in the beginning it was ADD but it seemed to have developed into ADHD.)"

column2: 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient) $5$5$5$"I am a 48 y.o university professor
column3: - after years of frustration and depression because of my procrastination habits and
column4: as I described it
column5: a lack of engagement between my brain and my body. I finally went into therapy just over a year ago at the urging of my wife and was diagnosed with ADHD. I started taking Adderall about 8 months ago. I have found that Adderall is very effective at helping me to focus and listen. It helps me to be more deliberate in my actions
column6: I'm not just drifting through the day. In my classroom I have found that I am able to listen to myself better and not be distracted by those students who give me that 'I'm so bored' look. One of the most interesting effects I've found is that I now actually hear and listen to the lyrics of songs! - never did that before. Looking back at my life
column7: all the way to when I was 6 years old I now recognize the symptoms that had always been there.  I feel that the treatment is working for me
column8: but as my doctor says
column9: the worst part is that I'm 48 and have only now finally taken care of a life-long problem. I take 30 mg. (15 mg standard 2 x a day). I did feel the side effects for about the first two or three days (teeth grinding and dry mouth) but they subsided and I don't have any issues with that now. I've lost a few pounds
column10: but I love to eat and  once I start eating
column11: my appetite is fine. I know that I'll have to continue with this
column12: probably for the rest of my life
column13: but I think of it as a simple compound that my body chemistry is simply missing - so it helps me a lot.

column1: Finally I would say to those of you suffering horrible side effects
column2: stop
column3: and get another opinion! If the side effects are that bad
column4: then you probably have a different problem. Amphetamines are an important drug that can work well for those who need it
column5: but if you don't
column6: you are abusing it. I thought that it would be like the speed we experimented with in high school
column7: but it's not. It is an essential part of my life now
column8: stigma or not -"

column1: 1477$Condition: Attention Deficit Disorder with Hyperactivity$10/1/2008 2:56:40 AM$Reviewer: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient) $3$3$5$"I've been taking Adderall for the past 3 months. The drug puts me in a good place but it doesn't seem to accomplish its actual purpose. I know I've become dependent on it even in this short period of time. Other users have noted this drug should be avoided if you have an addictive personality. I agree completely. It never occured to me that I might have ADD
column2: I was more concerned about my depression. Anyways
column3: my psych noted that I consume about three caffinated drinks a day along with a pack and a half of cigarettes. Now this drug is just another one of the stimulants I consume throughout the day to feel normal
column4: or at least like what I have come to consider ""normal."" Seriously
column5: I've met herion addicts who expressed concern when I told them I take Adderall. This drug is dangerous. Part of me thinks the companies behind it are guilty of endangering a lot of people
column6: but when I remember how I felt just after a few days of being off it
column7: you won't see me trying to stop them."

column1: 1478$Condition: Attention Deficit Disorder with Hyperactivity$9/27/2008 5:21:59 PM$Reviewer: DevinT
column2: 19-24 on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $4$3$4$"In high school
column3: my mom kept on me to do my schoolwork
column4: which was good.  However
column5: half way through college
column6: I started failing classes not having support
column7: so I went to the school counselor.

column1: She helped me out a bit with a schedule
column2: but still in crunch time
column3: halfway through a Term (quarter)
column4: I just couldn't focus for homework.  She brought up ADD
column5: so I contacted a Psychiatrist.

column1: My psychiatrist wasn't there
column2: so I had my initial assessment with a stand in.  She said I probably have Bipolar II (hypomanic-depressive).  Shocked
column3: I still geared up and looked up symptoms and this and that.  Sure
column4: so I have mild/moderate Bipolar...I thought everyone did.

column1: I had an appointment with my real psychiatrist
column2: and he was on the edge on if I was Bipolar or ADD.  Apparently
column3: a lot of the symptoms overlap.  It was possible I have both
column4: though
column5: so I scheduled another appointment and took Lamictal for BP2.

column1: The appointment after that was halfway through the term.  The mood swings were better
column2: but I still couldn't focus.  I was ""driven to distraction"" as he put it.  I would procrastinate to the point where I was not confident I could get the work done
column3: and then to cheer myself up
column4: I would do the very thing that I used to procrastinate (like a video game).

column1: He prescribed me this stuff
column2: Amphetamine Salts.  I took it the day after he prescribed it...and for good reason.  I had an assignment due the next morning.  I had a meeting to prepare for and run.  I had important people to email.

column1: It felt like I was sipping on a heavily caffeinated beverage all day.  That's when I'm most motivated.  I got all the emails sent out
column2: I ran the meeting just fine
column3: and I edited 8 pages of a document that I have been sitting on for over a year.

column1: The side effects I experienced were dry mouth
column2: muscle tension
column3: strange busts of tiredness that go away in 10 minutes
column4: high blood pressure (expected)
column5: feeling a little cold
column6: easy smiling
column7: and restlessness.

column1: It's been 3 days.  I actually WANT to do work now.  So weird..."
1479$Condition: Other$9/25/2008 7:13:23 PM$Reviewer: Success from St. Louis
column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $5$5$4$"I have been taking Adderall for six years now and what a difference it has made in my life.  I was finally diagnosed w/ADD when I was 20.  All my life I STRUGGLED through school (constantly daydreaming
column3: forgetting assignments
column4: awful  comprehension). I studied so hard and still earned mostly Cs. Teachers suggested to my parents that I be tested for ADD but I refused because I thought it meant I was dumb.  When I went away to college I did not have my parents reminding me to study or do homework.  The work load and subject matter was increasingly more difficult until one semester I ended up with a 1.5 GPA.  At that point I had enough of the struggle and I made an appointment with my Doctor.  After going through testing I was diagnosed with ADD and was put on Adderall.  I suddenly started to really enjoy school and on top of it all
column5: I really wasn't dumb.  I ended that semester with a 3.85 GPA.  I got an A in Quantitative Business Statistics and loved the class. I continued on with excellent grades and enjoying school and graduated from a State University with a Bachelor of Science.  My only regret is not starting this treatment sooner.  I think that years of struggling through school
column6: feeling left behind
column7: and feeling ""stupid"" has a negative impact on a child's development of self confidence
column8: self esteem
column9: and perseverance in life. For people that are ""on the fence"" about taking medication or allowing their child to take meds to treat truly DIAGNOSED ADD/ADHD
column10: ask yourself this..... If(you/your child) had diabetes would you not give your(self/child) insulin?  Everyone should have all the tools they need to succeed.  I am thrilled to be succeeding in life!!"

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $3$2$5$I am a mental health therapist

column4: and know in my heart that I am addicted
column5: and struggle with knowing this everyday.  With not wanting to refill my script
column6: but knowing that the addict in me will call my doctor and get a refill.  Knowing that I will become emotionless and cold

column9: and that the divide between my husband and I will grow bigger.  This medication helped me at first

column13: instead we are swapping scripts and pills and cleaning tips.  I caution everyone who is thinking about taking this drug to consider whether they can do it responsibly
column14: and their family history of addiction.  Reading these other reviews makes me feel much less alone
column15: but also very sad that so many people are having these problems.  I realize that I may need help to get off of it

column17: and then have two weeks without it.  The two weeks w/out it are so much better
column18: but the addict in me never listens.  Every month I think I can do it responsibly.  I just wonder

column20: that is so true.  Please be careful.
